Books ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/ec/WheresWally.jpg) - Magic Eye Books ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/35/MagicEyeCover.gif) - Dominos ![](https://www.museumofplay.org/app/uploads/2021/08/domino-square_0.png) - Magnets + Links ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/70/M_tic.jpg) - Parquetry Blocks ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Plastic_pattern_blocks.JPG/640px-Plastic_pattern_blocks.JPG) - Imaginarium Train Set + Thomas the Tank Engine ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Holzeisenbahn.jpg/640px-Holzeisenbahn.jpg) Play!! Yes, you. ## Discussion #1: Play How did you play? - Did you get bored? - Did you lose sense of time at any point? - Did anything become too difficult at any time? - What did you do at such times? Let us quickly review the [four central ideas in Play by Robert Caillois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man,_Play_and_Games). ## What is Flow? ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Flow.png){fig-align='center' width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: We will understand **Flow** from: 1. The book the book by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, titled [**Flow: The Psychology of Happiness**](Flow_%20The%20Psychology%20of%20Happiness%20-%20Csikszentmihalyi,%20Mihaly.pdf). First, let us learn to say his name!! ``{=html} Let us read the relevant pages (pp. 72-76, *Flow Activities*). This section nicely juxtaposes Csikszentmihalyi's ideas of `Flow` and Caillois ideas of `Play`, and states, as a finding of their research, that: >....every flow activity, whether it involved competition, chance, or any other dimension of experience, had this in common: It provided a sense of discovery, a creative feeling of transporting the person into a new reality. It pushed the person to higher levels of performance, and led to previously undreamed-of states of consciousness. In short, it transformed the self by making it more complex. 1. This video:

## Discussion #2 - Is the idea of Flow elusive? Is it similar to Play? - Do only some people get it, and then only at some times? - Was David Foster Wallace's talk somewhat self-deluding? - Then what is this *Empathy* stuff we talk about when we speak of Design Thinking? ## Pop "Quinx": Want still more Flow? No, that is not a bad spelling....why not? Go find me in this picture !!
![Pillar Rock](Pillar.JPG) ## {{< iconify fluent-mdl2 decision-solid >}} Conclusions - Flow is a `Zone of Play` between the rising `Floor of Boredom` and the approaching `Ceiling of Anxiety / Challenge` ( my "definition"!) - You need to use the Boredom to push away the Ceiling to stay in Play - To do that, you may need to: - Break Rules: Change how you experience / perceive things - Understand your Assumptions: ( More on this later) - Use and Create Surprises: Spot the Problem lurking in your Boredom - Grow More Skills to handle higher Complexity ## {{< iconify mingcute thought-line >}} Wait, But Why? - Flow is a great state to be in when you are working - It enables you to experience your work, your problem solving, in a way that is unique and hyper productive - And... - If you build / design some thing, wouldn't you want flow for the people who use that thing? - Flow is your gift to your users / customers / clients / audience !! - And so, it is both a beginning, and an end in Design!! ## {{< iconify ooui references-ltr >}} References 1.
